Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: High-Elevation Deciduous Forest Structure: A Test of the Slow-Seedling Hypothesis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research will investigate the relative contributions and interactions of seedling environment, canopy structure, climate variation, and the type and history of disturbance as factors contributing to dominance of deciduous broad-leaved species as opposed to needle-leaved conifers in alpine forests. Conventional understanding has held that alpine forests are dominated by needle-leaved conifers, but at some locales, broad-leaf alpine forests exist. A "slow-seedling" hypothesis articulated by William Bond posits that deciduous broad-leaved seedlings are superior competitors, largely because of their greater adaptability to localized changes in the availability of resources like light and soil moisture, while needle-leaved conifers are more tolerant to stressors like low temperatures and soil acidity. This project will increase knowledge regarding how species respond to variability in environmental conditions along an elevation gradient, especially at different stages of life. The project will help advance understanding in the geographic and biological sciences by improving basic knowledge of the controls on forest composition and structure of sensitive high-elevation forests. More specifically, the project will improve understanding of tree regeneration in alpine forest environments, especially when they are subjected to changes in climate or other environmental conditions. The project also will provide new insights regarding the ways in which shifts in the relative dominance of either deciduous broad-leaved species or needle-leaved conifers in the alpine environment would affect radiation absorption, the seasonality of carbon cycling, snow melt, and the susceptibility of forests to disturbance from fire or insect outbreaks. Data from this project will become available to other scholars through a set of databases. The project will provide special education and training opportunities for two undergraduate students, and an educational module will be developed and tested in middle-school classes. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The doctoral student whose dissertation research will be supported by this award will examine the specific ecological correlates important for seedling establishment, including light, elevation, canopy cover, soil nutrients, and landscape curvature. She will measure how structural properties differ between forest types across the elevation gradient, and she will examine the response of trees to climatic and disturbances histories in each forest type using tree-ring methods. The research will be conducted at eight sites in the forests on the slopes of the Japanese Alps in Chubu-Sangaku National Park in central Japan in collaboration with an experienced Japanese ecologist, Koichi Takahashi. Although conducted in Japan, the research findings will have utility to better understand forest dynamics around the nation, including in alpine forests of the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

In much of the northern hemisphere trees growing at the highest elevation on mountain tops are conifers (pine, spruce and fir) and  broad-leaved deciduous species (oak, maple, birch, etc) live below them. This overall pattern is thought to be related to differential requirements of conifers and broadleaved trees for soil nutrients with conifers found on harsher sites with lower nutrients. This pattern is not evident in high elevation forests in central Japan where broad-leaved deciduous species form treeline. This study tests whether Birch treeline in central Japan occurs at higher elevation due to higher nutrient sites than the conifer (fir, spruce) forest (Figure 1) as current theory predicts. 

Outcomes

Three approaches were used in the test the treeline soil nutrient hypothesis.  First, we examined the topographic (slope, aspect, elevation) and soil nutrient conditions found in both broad-leaved deciduous and conifer forests to determine if these properties explain their distribution pattern. We found that conifer distribution was explained by topography while broad-leaved deciduous forests were more nitrogen limited.  These patterns were more pronounced on volcanic than non-volcanic mountains (Figure 2).  Secondly, we identified forest structure and substrate (leaf litter, rocks, bare soil, etc.) across the forest types to determine how structure and dominance were influenced by substrate.  We also examined how structure and substrate influenced ontogeny or the life stages (seedlings, mature trees) of conifers and broad-leaved deciduous species. We found that life stage (seedling or tree, Figure 3b) and forest position (coniferous forest or broad-leaved deciduous forest, Figure 3c) were more important than species in separating species based on structure and substrate (Figure 3c).  This result is counter to what we hypothesized. Thirdly, we examined how conifers and broad-leaved deciduous species respond to climate (temperature and precipitation) using tree-ring analysis.  The analysis indicates that conifer tree-ring widths were limited by low winter temperatures, whereas the broad-leaved deciduous trees were limited by low summer temperature and high summer precipitation (Figure 4).

Broader Impacts

Benefit to society - Results from this study has implications for how forests may or may not change in the future, and whether they will serve as a source or sink of carbon. This work may contribute to policy development and decision making on forest management and mitigating the effects of climate change. These high elevation forests are a tourist destination, particularly in the fall to view the contrasting colors of coniferous trees with the yellow-orange fall foliage of the broad-leaved deciduous trees.  Understanding how broad-leaved deciduous trees will respond to climate change at high elevations as well where it reproduces will be important for the local economy through tourism.

Dissemination of project results – Project data and analysis will be made available to the Centre for Global Environmental Research at the Japanese National Institute for Environmental Studies and the Japan Climate Data Project. These agencies model past, present and future changes in climate and vegetation.  The tree-ring chronologies will be made available on the International Tree-Ring Data Base website and forest structure data will be accessible on the Penn State University online data repository once they have been published. Results have been presented at national (American Association of Geographers and Ecological Society of America) and international professional (Ameridendro in Argentina and the Japanese Alps meeting in Japan) conferences as well as an invited talk at the Harvard Forest and two informal seminars in Japan. The manuscripts from this research are being prepared to be published in scholarly journals, particularly those with an international readership.

Promotion teaching, training and learning - This project will also provide summer internships for one Penn State University and one Shinshu University undergraduate student. The experience gained from working in the field will help interest these students in pursuing careers in geography or another STEM discipline. Additionally, three undergraduate students assisted in the laboratory analysis of samples.

 

Participation of under-represented groups - Amanda Young presented her research experiences as a woman physical geographer to a group of middle school girls during the Supporting Young Women in Geography (SYWIG) Day at Penn State University. This event is oriented towards middle school girls to introduce them to the diverse field of geography and is sponsored by Supporting Women in Geography (SWIG), of which Amanda served as president (2012-2013).

Enhance infrastructure for research and education - This research was conducted in collaboration with faculty from Shinshu University in Japan and Penn State University.  The collaboration has developed an international research bond between the two universities that was initiated in 2012 by Amanda Young.
